item.title: The Connectivity You Need For Digital Transformation
item.description: By: John Shepler Almost every business is currently undergoing some form of digital transformation, which involves transitioning from traditional, paper-based methods to digital and online processes. This shift promises faster, more efficient operations that can reduce costs and expand customer reach. However, establishing the necessary infrastructure to support this digital transformation is crucial. Conducting Business Primarily Online While most products and services aren’t inherently digital, the tools supporting them are. From identifying potential customers to converting them into buyers, serving those customers, and maintaining product flow, every aspect has a digital element.

item.title: Will SD-WAN Eat MPLS?
item.description: SD-WAN, a trending service, is considered a potential alternative to MPLS networks, with cost comparisons hinting at a potential shift similar to how MPLS replaced Frame Relay. The Need for Network Solutions Computer networking is crucial in today’s world, connecting various devices like desktops, laptops, tablets, and even specialized equipment. This interconnectedness is vital for both basic functionality and accessing cloud-based applications. Traditional Networking Solutions Private point-to-point circuits offer complete network control and high performance but come with high costs and lengthy setup times.

item.title: The Software Defined Network Comes to Austin
item.description: By: John Shepler The Software Defined Network (SDN) has arrived, shifting away from the abstract and promising practical improvements for businesses. Here’s how SDN can benefit your company. Why Software? SDN aims to replace fixed hardware functions with adaptable software. While this may seem like simplification, it involves intricate coding on more generic hardware like microprocessors. The advantage lies in the easy replication and remote modification of software components. The Idea of Virtualization

item.title: Can Satellite Be Part of Your SD-WAN?
item.description: By: John Shepler Software Defined Networks (SDN) and Software Defined Wide Area Networks (SD-WAN) are seeing increased implementation due to their ability to offer cost-effective, high-quality bandwidth for businesses. SD-WAN is sometimes the sole option for acceptable bandwidth in remote or rural locations. These software-defined networks act as a blend of various connection technologies, intelligently maximizing the use of each available connection, including satellite. The Need For SD Networks Traditionally, connecting to the internet or a cloud service provider involved ordering a “last mile” connection from a business location or a dedicated point-to-point line between two points, like an office and a cloud provider.

item.title: Various Flavors of Business Internet Access
item.description: By: John Shepler While it may seem like all internet connections are the same, the way you connect significantly impacts your experience. This article will help determine the best option for you: Dedicated or Shared Internet Access. What is Dedicated Internet Access? There are two primary methods to connect to the internet: Shared Internet Access, common for consumers and wireless services, and Dedicated Internet Access (DIA). Dedicated Access mirrors managing an internal network.

item.title: Can SD-WAN Solve Your Low Bandwidth Problem?
item.description: By: John Shepler Software Defined Networking (SDN) and SD-WAN, specifically, can’t magically produce more bandwidth. Upgrading to a dedicated, high-bandwidth service with a service level agreement from a reputable carrier is a more straightforward solution. However, SD-WAN can offer faster and more reliable bandwidth at a lower cost. The Root of Bandwidth Issues Businesses grappling with bandwidth issues often face budget constraints that limit them to low-cost options or struggle with the unavailability of suitable services in their location.

item.title: SDN Performance Takes a Leaf of Faith
item.description: By: John Shepler Cloud computing has highlighted the importance of reliable internet connections, known as WANs (Wide Area Networks). In the past, slow file transfers or unreliable internet were acceptable because crucial tasks were handled within the company’s internal network. However, now that businesses rely on cloud services, the performance of the WAN is just as crucial as the internal network (LAN). WAN Challenges The main challenge with WANs is that businesses don’t control them like they do their internal networks.

item.title: WANs That Act Like LANs
item.description: Local Area Networks (LANs) are so commonplace in businesses that they often go unnoticed, much like the electrical outlets we use daily. They provide a standardized way to connect devices, making them function seamlessly without users needing to consider technical details. Networks vs Utilities LANs can be compared to electricity: reliable and readily available. Just as we don’t think about voltage variations, we expect LANs to work without needing to understand the intricacies of Ethernet standards.
